title: Abortion legislation spurs dueling protests inside Florida Capitol
description: Competing chants were "Our lives, our voice" and  "I vote pro-life first."
text_headers: Abortion legislation spurs dueling protests inside Florida Capitol
text: Abortion legislation spurs dueling protests inside Florida CapitolNews Sports Entertainment Opinion Email Us Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals  NEWSAbortion legislation spurs dueling protests inside Florida Capitol Tori Lynn SchneiderTallahassee DemocratBoth sides of Florida's abortion debate clashed inside the Capitol rotunda Tuesday.Around 150 activists organized by Planned Parenthood arrived first, shouting chants heard throughout the fourth and fifth floors, including "Our lives, our voice!" and  "Kelli Stargel's not my mom!" Stargel, a Republican state senator from Lakeland, is behind a bill (SB 404) that would require parental consent for minors seeking an abortion. Current law requires parents only to be notified.Nearly 80 others from multiple anti-abortion organizations, such as Students for Life of America, arrived later. They weaved their way between their counterparts with signs reading "I vote pro-life first" and "I am the pro-life generation." Capitol Police separated the two groups and cordoned them to opposite sides of the rotunda. Officers also told them to stop shouting when the Senate went into a floor session at 3 p.m.The Senate had been scheduled to take up Stargel's bill on Tuesday, but consideration of the measure was moved to Thursday. Before the anti-abortion activists gathered, one woman stood along the fifth-floor railing of the rotunda, above the Planned Parenthood organizers, in her own silent counter-protest. Pam Stenzel held a sign reading "conceived in rape ... thanks, mom for my life," as she listened to the group chant. Stenzel, who spent most of her life in Minneapolis but now lives in Tampa, said she supports the bill. She believes parents should be involved in a decision that is life-changing for a minor. "My life has value; I matter," she said. "My body matters. And I don't believe I deserved the death penalty for the crime of my father."Contact Tori Lynn Schneider at tschneider@tallahassee.com or on Twitter @photoriphy.
